text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text with a rectangular framed miniature inset between text blocks; text appears above and below the image, with a decorated initial beginning the text block below. Wide margins are relatively unadorned aside from the miniature frame and rubrication.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata with regular, professional book hand execution, extensive use of abbreviations and rubrics in red

color_scheme.color_usage: Ultramarine blue dominates the sky and knightly surcoats to denote importance; gold leaf frames the scene and highlights armor fittings to signal status; verdigris green defines ground and foliage; red (vermillion) appears in rubric text and shield devices; layered application of pigments with white lead highlights on armor and horses; original colors well-preserved with minimal darkening.

features: Central mounted knight in foreground on prancing horse
Two standing figures to right balancing the combatants
Background trees and hill forming a low horizon line

decorative_elements: Historiated initial ‘O’ with pen-flourished border below image
Stylized trees and bushes as background motif

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in dark brown ink with consistent line weight
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle linear hatching on armor surfaces, white lead highlighting on folds and metal
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping rather than true linear perspective; foreground figures larger than background elements

content_theme.scene_description: A single, full-color miniature depicts five armored knights on horseback engaged in combat. Central horse and rider face left, the knight raising a sword in his right hand and grasping reins in his left. To his left, a second knight lowers a lance aimed at the central figure; his pennoned lance overlaps the central knight’s helmet. Behind them stand three auxiliary chevaliers: two in full helm and one bareheaded figure wearing a simple crown and long red robe, holding horse reins. The white warhorse of the central knight is caparisoned with blue and gold fringed harness, its saddlecloth edged with fleur-de-lis motifs in shell gold. The riders wear full plate armor with blue-edged surcoats bearing heraldic devices in red and gold. Grass blades and stylized bushes cover the foreground; a gently rolling hill and a trio of tufted trees occupy the midground, beneath an ultramarine sky. Figures are arranged in overlapping tiers: the central combatants in the lower register, the observers elevated slightly to the right. Armor surfaces show fine hatching; lances and swords are rendered with metallic silver tones. The red and green robes of the onlookers contrast with the cool palette of armor and landscape, reinforcing the hierarchy of active and passive participants.

secular: Mounted knights in full plate armor with blue-edged surcoats and lances
Two courtiers in red and green robes, one crowned, holding horse reins

technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent: pigments vivid, gold leaf burnished and intact, minimal pigment flaking or abrasion to armor highlights
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso preparation under gold leaf border
Visible underdrawing in brown ink beneath painted areas
Even ruling pattern at regular intervals

Memory aid for recounting martial exploits

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature likely originates from a late 14th-century Franco-Burgundian workshop, reflecting the era’s fusion of chivalric narrative and courtly display. The professional Gothic textura script and lavish ultramarine and gold point to a high-status commission, perhaps for a princely patron keen to perpetuate martial values. The centralization of the mounted combatants underscores the knightly ethos, while the careful overlapping of figures and limited landscape evoke emerging concerns with spatial coherence in Burgundian illumination. The color hierarchy—blue for active protagonists, red and green for passive observers—reinforces narrative focus and social distinction. Technically, the use of gesso relief beneath gold and fine hatching on armor reveals sophisticated studio practice, comparable to illuminations in the Chronicles of Froissart. Iconographically, the fleur-de-lis motifs situate the scene within a royal context, suggesting a parallel between fictional or historical combat and dynastic legitimacy. Compared with contemporaneous works from the Parisian atelier of the Rohan Master, this image shares a dynamic diagonal thrust and naturalistic foliage, while diverging in its more subdued depth treatment. Overall, the miniature bridges traditional manuscript iconography and the evolving pictorial ambitions of late medieval courtly art.
